description: From Middle English halyday, holyday, halidei, haliȝdei, from Old English hāliġdæġ (“holy day, Sabbath”), equivalent to holy +‎ day. Compare West Frisian hjeldei (“holiday”), Danish helligdag (“holiday”), Norwegian helligdag (“holiday”), Swedish helgdag (“holiday, feast”).

entries.meaning: A day on which a festival, religious event, or national celebration is traditionally observed.
A day declared free from work by the state or government.
(chiefly UK, Australia) A period of one or more days taken off work for leisure and often travel; often plural.
examples: Synonyms: leave, time off, (US) vacation; see also Thesaurus:vacation

entries.meaning: (chiefly UK, Australia) A period during which pupils do not attend their school; often plural; rarely used for students at university (usually: vacation).
examples: I want to take a French course this summer holiday.

entries.meaning: (finance) A period during which, by agreement, the usual payments are not made.
A gap in coverage, e.g. of paint on a surface, or sonar imagery.

verbs.description: holiday (third-person singular simple present holidays, present participle holidaying, simple past and past participle holidayed) (chiefly Britain)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To take a period of time away from work or study.
(Britain, intransitive) To spend a period of time in recreational travel.
